message.content:
cs.IR, cs.SI, cs.SOC, cs.CYBER, cs.CL 

This paper focuses on studying information-seeking behavior and access to alternative viewpoints following a shocking news event, specifically in the context of gun control/rights in the United States. This topic is highly relevant to the fields of information retrieval (cs.IR) and social media (cs.SI), as well as social computing (cs.SOC) and cybersecurity (cs.CYBER) due to the potential impact of online information on public opinion and policy decisions. Additionally, the use of information-theoretic measures to quantify diversity of web domains and browsing patterns suggests a potential connection to natural language processing (cs.CL).
